newsitem.title: KUWAIT: Kuwait parliament discusses state 1996/97 budget.
newsitem.headline: Kuwait parliament discusses state 1996/97 budget.

text.p: Kuwait's parliament started discussions on Tuesday of a proposed 4.21 billion dinar ($14 billion) state budget with a forecast net deficit of 1.21 billion dinars for the fiscal year which started July 1.
Politicians and economists expect parliament to complete the debate and approve the budget retroactively ahead of the October 7 parliamentary elections in the oil-rich state.
"I think the budget could be approved with some minor changes," said one economist. "They could ratify it Tuesday or Wednesday, followed by a closing session on Saturday."
Total revenue in the proposed 1996/97 budget is put at three billion dinars, including 2.56 billion dinars in oil earnings.
Oil revenue is calculated at a conservative weighted- average price of $13 for a barrel of oil, unchanged from the past two years although world prices have been much higher this year.
The world benchmark Brent crude is currently trading in London at $22.65 a barrel. Kuwait has a daily oil output of about two million barrels.
In July the government said it expected to halve the 1.32 billion dinar forecast deficit for the last fiscal year mainly because of higher world oil prices. The initial budget
proposal presented to parliament for the 1995/96 year forecast a 1.32 billion dinar deficit and revenues of 2.91 billion dinars.
By law 10 percent of total revenues is placed in a special fund for future generations, making the gross projected deficits 1.51 billion dinars for 1996/97 and 1.61 billion dinars for 1995/96.
Deficits are traditionally financed from general reserves in the form of a debt to the future generations fund.
Since the 1990-91 Gulf crisis, Kuwait's foreign investment portfolio has fallen to about $35 billion from over $100 billion. ($1=0.3 dinars)
